awd_titl_txt: Collaborative Research:  RUI SG:  Evolutionary relationships and systematics of riverweeds (Podostemaceae)
awd_abstract_narration:
The riverweed family (Podostemaceae) is the largest entirely aquatic family of flowering plants and provides important habitats and food sources for many aquatic animals.  Many of the estimated 300 riverweed species are narrowly distributed and incompletely known, and genealogical relationships within the family are uncertain.  This project will produce the first family-wide estimate of genealogical relationships among riverweeds using DNA sequence data, and a better understanding of relationships, morphological variation, and will clarify the number of different species that exist. This project will provide broad training opportunities for undergraduate students in both field and laboratory research, including molecular biology, plant structural analyses, database development and management, and taxonomomy at two Primarily Undergraduate Institutions located in Connecticut and Kentucky. DNA sequence data generated by the project will be disseminated via publicly accessible databases, and newly collected plant specimens will be deposited within natural history museums.

This project will produce a molecular systematic and phylogenetic analysis of the flowering plant family Podostemaceae, and a taxonomic monograph of the genus Apiniagia (Podostemaceae). Podostemaceae species exhibit high phenotypic plasticity and have highly modified growth forms, both of which contribute to taxonomic confusion. This project will assemble a well-sampled and robust phylogeny of the family, with a focus on neotropical taxa, using morphological data and molecular data obtained via high throughput DNA sequencing. Molecular data will be collected from whole chloroplast genomes and select mitochondrial and nuclear loci. This phylogeny will be used to circumscribe all neotropical genera of Podostemaceae, understand convergent patterns of morphological evolution, and test the hypothesis that the distribution of the neotropical Podostemoideae clade is largely explained by major river capture events during the Cenozoic. Using the results of the phylogenetic analyses in combination with morphological investigations, a taxonomic monograph for the genus Apiniagia will be produced. This genus is the largest, most morphologically complex, and taxonomically difficult genus of neotropical Podostemaceae. The monograph will include nomenclatural updates, morphological descriptions, and taxonomic keys, in addition to newly developed online resources to broadly disseminate the results. This project will also produce a new, free tool for the systematics community, a Darwin Core Archive export option for the Symbiota platform specific to monographic data sets.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
The riverweed family (Podostemaceae) is the largest entirely aquatic family of flowering plants and provides crucial tropical habitats and food sources for many aquatic animals. Many of the estimated 300 riverweed species are narrowly distributed (often occur in only one to two rivers) and incompletely known, and evolutionary relationships within the family are unclear; thus, their conservation is uncertain. Moreover, species in this family are reported to be "foundation species", i.e., key to the functioning of the local ecosystem.  Even so, the basic question of how many genera and species are in this family remains to be answered. The main aims of this project were to: 1) conduct a phylogenetic analysis of Podostemaceae using molecular data from a combination of newly and previously collected specimens; 2) create a monograph of Apinagia, the largest, most morphologically complex, and taxonomically difficult genus of neotropical Podostemaceae; and 3) provide training opportunities for undergraduates in both field and laboratory research.

A collecting trip in 2019 resulted in 40 new collections of Podostemaceae from an area that had been relatively unsampled previously. Several of these collections represent species new to science. Phylogenetic analyses of molecular data from these new collections, as well as already available collections, resulted in the most complete analysis to date in terms of the number of taxa and characters included. These analyses include representatives of the family worldwide, with a particular focus on neotropical taxa. An important result of this work will be to define the boundaries of genera and species in the neotropics; these results will be important to conservation efforts focused both riverweed species and on other tropical riverine species that utilize the riverweeds for habitat or a food source. Our sequencing results also produced five annotated chloroplast genomes that will not only help studies of Podostemaceae, but studies on the evolution of the plastid genome in flowering plants. Data obtained for this project is still being analyzed, and once a final phylogeny is complete, monographic work and biogeographical analyses will be conducted.

In addition to the new collections and phylogenetic work mentioned above, this project produced several other positive outcomes. Over 1200 duplicate specimens from the Western Connecticut State Herbarium Podostemaceae collection are now deposited at the University of Michigan Herbarium, increasing their availability to the research community. This work also strengthened international collaborations with scientists in Brazil, Hungary, and Switzerland who also work on the riverweeds. A particularly exciting outcome of this project was the discovery that many-hundreds of invertebrates find habitat on a single plant of Podostemaceae.  Thus, demonstrating the "foundation species" nature of these plants.

Funds provided by this grant were used to train five undergraduate students at Eastern Kentucky University in both field and laboratory research. One of these students has gone on to receive a Master of Science degree and is entering a PhD program. Data from newly collected specimens and newly generated molecular sequence data were made publicly available online. Results from work funded by this grant was also presented at multiple departmental seminars and professional meetings.
